questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following is a polyene antifungal agent?
questions.explanation:
Amphotericin B is a polyene antifungal. Other polyene antifungals are: • Amphotericin B 551 
Sold by @itachibot • Nystatin • Natamycin • Hamycin Amphotericin B is the least toxic among polyenes and is used systemically for fungal 
infections. Nystatin and hamycin have high systemic toxicity and are used only for local and 
topical actions.

questions.question: Question 2: What is the site of action of amphotericin B in fungi?
questions.explanation:
The site of action of amphotericin B in fungi is the cell membrane. Amphotericin B binds to the ergosterol in the cell membrane of fungi and forms pores or 
channels. They increase the permeability of the membrane to ions and cause leakage of cytosolic 
molecules. This leads to a loss of integrity of the cell membrane and causes fungicidal effects. Recent evidence suggests that the amphotericin B sequesters ergosterol from lipid layers, much 
like a sponge, resulting in fungal cell death.

questions.question: Question 3: Which formulation of amphotericin B has the highest risk of nephrotoxicity?
questions.explanation:
Nephrotoxicity risk is highest with conventional amphotericin B. Conventional amphotericin B (C-AMB) is not a lipid-based formulation of amphotericin 
B. Amphotericin B is insoluble in water, hence C-AMB is formulated by complexing with bile salt 
deoxycholate to make it suitable for intravenous infusion. Nephrotoxicity risk with amphotericin B formulations in decreasing order: • C-AMB > Amphotericin B lipid complex (ABLC) > Liposomal amphotericin B (L-AMB) • All lipid formulations of amphotericin B (ABLC, L-AMB, ABCD) are less nephrotoxic than 
conventional amphotericin B Note: Amphotericin B colloidal dispersion (ABCD) has not been compared with other lipid-based 
formulations

questions.question:
Question 4: A diabetic patient presents with periorbital swelling as shown below. She complains of 
significant visual impairment and a fungal etiology is suspected. What is the most appropriate 
drug for this patient? 542 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given scenario is suggestive of invasive mucormycosis in the form of orbital cellulitis. 
Intravenous administration of amphotericin B is the treatment of choice for invasive 
mucormycosis. Mucormycosis is an opportunistic infection seen in patients with diabetes mellitus, leukaemia, 
lymphoma and other immunocompromised states. The most prevalent species is Rhizopus Oryza. 552 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 5: A patient diagnosed with mucormycosis is being treated with intravenous amphotericin B. 
Following administration of the drug, he starts experiencing chills, fever and dyspnea. These 
symptoms occur most frequently with which formulation?
questions.explanation:
Development of fever and chills following intravenous administration is suggestive of 
infusion-related reactions which occur most frequently with amphotericin B colloidal dispersions. Infusion-related adverse events are commonly seen with amphotericin B and it has been 
nicknamed 'shake and bake syndrome' due to the associated chills and fever. Decreasing order of frequency of infusion-related reactions with amphotericin B formulations: Amphotericin B colloidal dispersions (ABCD) > conventional amphotericin B (C-AMB) > 
amphotericin B lipid complex (ABLC) > liposomal amphotericin B (L-AMB).

questions.question:
Question 6: An immunocompromised patient with invasive mucormycosis is administered intravenous 
amphotericin B. Which frequently associated electrolyte disturbance would you be concerned 
about?
questions.explanation:
Amphotericin B causes hypokalemia and hence potassium levels should be monitored in this 
patient. Amphotericin B can cause renal tubular acidosis and renal wasting of K+ and Mg2+ leading to 
hypokalemia and hypomagnesemia during and several weeks after therapy. Potassium 
supplements are required in around one-third of patients on prolonged amphotericin B therapy.

questions.question:
Question 7: An HIV-positive patient presents with headache and nuchal stiffness. The CD4 count is 90 
and CSF sample with India-ink staining shows the presence of encapsulated yeast cells. 
Which of the following is the treatment of choice for the patient?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario and the presence of encapsulated yeast cells in CSF with India ink 
staining are suggestive of cryptococcal meningitis. Amphotericin B plus flucytosine is the 
treatment of choice for this patient. Cryptococcal meningitis is an AIDS-defining opportunistic fungal CNS infection that generally 
occurs in untreated patients, with CD4+ T cell counts <100/L. In cryptococcal meningitis, amphotericin B combined with flucytosine is the current gold 
standard treatment in immunocompromised patients, especially in AIDS patients. In non-immunocompetent patients, the role of additional flucytosine along with amphotericin B is 
less clear. Oral fluconazole is used for consolidation and maintenance therapy after two weeks of induction 
therapy with amphotericin B.

questions.question: Question 8: Identify the wrongly matched pair of antifungals with its mechanism of action:

options.b: Flucytosine : Inhibits microtubule synthesis and thus hinders mitosis

questions.explanation:
Flucytosine acts by inhibition of fungal DNA synthesis. It is a pyrimidine antimetabolite. After uptake into fungal cells, fungal cytosine deaminase 
activates it to 5-fluorouracil, which is an anticancer drug. This is further converted into 
metabolites that inhibit thymidylate synthase which is necessary for DNA synthesis. Thus fungal 
DNA synthesis is inhibited. Mammalian cells are spared as they lack cytosine deaminase enzyme. 553 
Sold by @itachibot Flucytosine has clinically useful activity against (3C): • Cryptococcus • Candida species • Agents causing chromoblastomycosis

questions.question:
Question 9: 544 
Sold by @itachibot A washerman presents with itchy, annular scaly plaques in the groin. He is prescribed with an 
antifungal that acts by interfering with mitosis. Identify the drug.
questions.explanation:
Itchy annular plaques in the groin are suggestive of tinea cruris and the drug most likely given 
was griseofulvin which acts by interfering with fungal mitosis. Microtubule function is necessary for the formation of the mitotic spindle during cell division. 
Griseofulvin inhibits microtubule function and thereby disrupts mitotic spindle formation and 
inhibits cell division. Tinea cruris is a dermatophytosis involving the groin and is also known as jock itch or dhobi's 
itch.

questions.question: Question 10: To which of the following patients will you not prescribe griseofulvin?

options.a: A middle aged man with tinea capitis

questions.explanation:
Griseofulvin is not useful in the treatment of tinea versicolor. It is treated with topical azoles. Tinea capitis, tinea cruris and tinea pedis are dermatophytoses. Griseofulvin is indicated only for 
dermatophytoses caused by species of Microsporum, Epidermophyton, and Trichophyton. It is 
considered the drug of choice for tinea capitis in children. It is reserved only for large topical tinea 
infections when topical therapy is inadequate. Tinea versicolor is not a dermatophytosis. It is a superficial mycosis caused by lipophilic yeast 
Malassezia.

questions.question: Question 11: Which of the following can cause contraceptive failure in a lady on oral contraceptive pills?
questions.explanation:
Griseofulvin is a cytochrome enzyme inducer and can cause contraceptive failure when taken with 
oral contraceptive pills. It induces hepatic CYP enzymes and can increase the metabolism of drugs. Warfarin metabolism 
is increased and the dose has to be adjusted according to the change in response. Estrogen 
metabolism is also increased thereby reducing the efficacy of low-dose estrogen-based oral 
contraceptives. Note: Ketoconazole is a cytochrome enzyme inhibitor.

questions.question: Question 12: Fungal cell wall synthesis is altered by which of the following drugs?
questions.explanation:
554 
Sold by @itachibot Fungal cell wall synthesis is altered by caspofungin. 1,3--D glucan is an essential component of the fungal cell wall which maintains cell 
integrity. Echinocandin group of antifungals like caspofungin, anidulafungin, and micafungin acts 
by inhibiting the synthesis of 1,3--D-glucan and thereby weakens the fungal cell wall and 
increases the osmotic susceptibility. Echinocandins are fungicidal against Candida species. They show fungistatic activity against 
Aspergillus species.

questions.question:
Question 13: 545 
Sold by @itachibot What is the mechanism of triazoles?

options.a: Interferes with DNA and RNA synthesis
options.d: Inhibits epoxidation of squalene in fungi

questions.explanation:
Triazoles act by inhibition of ergosterol synthesis. The azole group inhibits the fungal cytochrome P450 enzyme called 14- -sterol demethylase and 
results in an impairment of conversion of lanosterol to ergosterol. This results in the depletion of 
membrane ergosterol. Azole antifungals are of two types: • Imidazoles - clotrimazole, ketoconazole, luliconazole • Triazoles - itraconazole, fluconazole, voriconazole, posaconazole and isavuconazole

questions.question:
Question 14: A patient was diagnosed with coccidioidal meningitis. What is the drug of choice for the 
condition?
questions.explanation:
Fluconazole is the drug of choice for coccidioidal meningitis caused by Coccidioides immitis 
because of better CSF penetration. Itraconazole is also effective in this condition but it is not the drug of choice. Amphotericin B is 
indicated in patients in whom triazoles have failed. Note: Amphotericin B is the drug of choice for initial treatment of cryptococcal meningitis caused 
by Cryptococcus neoformans and fluconazole is used for maintenance therapy.

questions.question:
Question 15: A middle aged man presents with the condition shown in the image. Which of the following 
drugs can cause this condition?
questions.explanation:
The image above depicts gynecomastia and can be caused by ketoconazole due to its 
antiandrogenic action. Ketoconazole use results in various antiandrogenic effects. It decreases testosterone production 
and displaces testosterone from protein binding sites in plasma. It also decreases hydrocortisone 
production, especially at higher doses. Adverse effects that can occur are gynecomastia, loss of 
hair, libido, and oligozoospermia. Fluconazole, itraconazole and voriconazole do not have antiandrogenic action. 555 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 16: Which of the following is not an indication for ketoconazole use?
questions.explanation:
Ketoconazole is not indicated for use in Addison’s disease. It is a potent nonselective inhibitor of adrenal and gonadal steroidogenesis by inhibiting 17 
 -hydroxylase enzymes which are involved in steroid hormone synthesis and it can hence worsen 
Addison's disease. However, this property also makes it useful in the treatment of Cushing’s 
syndrome. Azoles interfere with leishmanial cell membrane biosynthesis and are therefore used in dermal 
leishmaniasis and kala-azar.

questions.question:
Question 17: While administering which of the following drugs will you counsel patients regarding 
transient visual and auditory hallucinations?
questions.explanation:
Transient visual or auditory hallucinations are commonly seen with the use of intravenous 
voriconazole. These usually occur at night. Other side effects of voriconazole are: • Hepatotoxicity • Prolonged QTc interval and increased risk of torsades de pointes • Anaphylactoid reaction when given intravenously

questions.question:
Question 18: Omeprazole dose is reduced when given along with voriconazole because of what action of the 
latter drug?
questions.explanation:
Voriconazole is a strong inhibitor and substrate of CYP2C19. Concomitant omeprazole 
administration can result in increased omeprazole levels because of inhibition of metabolism. In a patient on omeprazole 40 mg/day, the dose of omeprazole should be reduced to half when 
voriconazole is initiated. Additionally, higher levels of omeprazole can also interfere in 
voriconazole metabolism as omeprazole also inhibits CYP2C19.

questions.question:
Question 19: In a patient with athlete's foot, which keratolytic ointment would you prescribe to enhance 
treatment outcome?
questions.explanation:
Salicylic acid is a keratolytic agent that can be prescribed to enhance the treatment outcome in 
patients with athlete's foot (i.e. tinea pedis). Salicylic acid accelerates the desquamation of the stratum corneum. It is used in combination with 
a fungistatic drug called benzoic acid because eradication of infection is possible only if the 
infected stratum corneum is shed. This combination is called Whitfield's ointment and is used in 
the treatment of tinea pedis.

questions.question:
Question 20: A patient presented with multiple annular itchy skin lesions with central clearing over his 
back. You may prescribe any of the following except?
questions.explanation:
556 
Sold by @itachibot Pruritic annular skin lesions with central clearing are suggestive of dermatophytosis for which 
amphotericin B must not be prescribed. Azoles, terbinafine, and griseofulvin are indicated for the 
treatment of dermatophytosis. Dermatophytes are inhibited by amphotericin B but drug concentrations attained in the skin are 
very low and ineffective for the treatment of dermatophytosis. The uses of amphotericin B are: • Treatment of choice in invasive mucormycosis • Candida albicans infection • Cryptococcus neoformans infection • Endemic mycosis

questions.question: Question 21: Which of the following drugs is not used to treat candida infections?
questions.explanation:
Griseofulvin is not used to treat candida infection. It is active against most dermatophytes but not 
against candida and other fungi causing deep mycosis. Ketoconazole, nystatin, and amphotericin B are used in the treatment of candida infections.

questions.question: Question 22: Which of the following is not true about antifungal drugs?

options.a: Amphotericin B is more effective parenterally
options.c: Ciclopirox olamine is effective in systemic mycoses
options.d: Fluconazole is effective orally as well as intravenously

questions.explanation:
Ciclopirox olamine is a topical antifungal agent and is not effective in systemic mycoses. Ciclopirox olamine is a broad spectrum fungicidal agent that acts by chelating trivalent metal ions 
which leads to inhibition of the metal-dependent enzyme that degrades free radicals. It is available 
as a nail lacquer formulation in the treatment of onychomycosis. Option A: Amphotericin B is more effective parenterally for systemic mycoses. However, local or 
topical administration of amphotericin B drops is used in mycotic corneal ulcers. Option B: The absorption of griseofulvin is less when administered orally but microfining the drug 
particles increases the absorption. Option D: Fluconazole can be administered orally as well as intravenously.

questions.question:
Question 23: Topical antifungal agents have no role in the treatment of patients with which of the following 
conditions?
questions.explanation:
Topical antifungal agents have no role in the treatment of subcutaneous mycoses like 
chromoblastomycosis. Itraconazole is the first-line antifungal indicated in this condition. Topical antifungal agents are used in the treatment of: • Dermatophytosis • Candidiasis 557 
Sold by @itachibot • Piedra • Tinea versicolor • Tinea nigra • Fungal keratitis

questions.question: Question 24: Which of the following antifungal drugs are used topically?
questions.explanation:
Tolnaftate, butenafine, naftifine, and clotrimazole are used topically. Allylamine antifungals available for topical application are: • Terbinafine • Naftifine • Butenafine Azoles that are used topically are: • Clotrimazole • Miconazole • Econazole Tolnaftate is a topical synthetic antifungal agent. It distorts the mycelial growth of yeast-like fungi 
and molds. It is effective in the treatment of dermatomycosis and tinea.

questions.question:
Question 25: A 48-year-old woman presented with yellowish discolouration of toenails. The discolouration 
spread proximally as a streak in the nail and later, the entire nail separated from the nailbed. 
What is the mechanism of action of the drug of choice for her?

options.b: Binding to ergosterol and altering membrane functions
options.c: Formation of pore in cell membrane

questions.explanation:
The clinical features are suggestive of tinea unguium or onychomycosis. The drug of choice is oral 
terbinafine which acts by inhibition of ergosterol synthesis. Terbinafine acts as a non-competitive inhibitor of squalene epoxidase, an early step enzyme in the 
synthesis of fungal ergosterol. This results in the accumulation of sterol squalene which is toxic to 
the organism. The efficacy of terbinafine in onychomycosis is improved when combined with amorolfine 5% nail 
lacquer.

questions.question:
Question 26: A farmer presented with complaints of redness and excessive watering from the right eye. 
Slit-lamp examination reveals the following finding. Microscopy of the corneal ulcer scraping 
shows branched septate hyphae. Which of the following drugs can be used in the treatment of 
this patient?
questions.explanation:
Slit-lamp examination showing a corneal ulcer with satellite lesions and a thick hypopyon are 
suggestive of mycotic keratitis (fungal corneal ulcer) while branched septate hyphae are seen 
with Aspergillus and Fusarium. Natamycin 5% suspension is the drug of choice in this condition. Treatment of fungal corneal ulcer: 558 
Sold by @itachibot • Topical antifungals: Aspergillus and Fusarium infections are treated with natamycin, 
amphotericin B and voriconazole while Candida infections are treated with nystatin. • Systemic antifungals: Ketoconazole or voriconazole may be needed if there is a severe corneal 
ulcer, perforated ulcer, or suspicion of endophthalmitis.

questions.question: Question 27: Voriconazole is not effective against which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Voriconazole is not effective against mucormycosis. Mucormycosis is treated by amphotericin B. Posaconazole can also be used. However, other azoles 
are not effective against this fungus. Voriconazole is the drug of choice for the treatment of aspergillosis. It can also be used for 
Candida species (including glabrata and krusei), Scedosporium and Fusarium. 559 
Sold by @itachibot First Line Drugs for Tuberculosis
